questions.text: A previously healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because she refuses to use her left arm after tripping over a stone that morning on the way to the supermarket while holding her mother's hand. She did not hit the ground. Growth and development are appropriate for age. She appears anxious. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The left forearm is held close to her body in partial extension and pronation. There is no swelling or bruising of the elbow or the forearm. Palpation of the proximal radius produces pain. The child cries on attempting to passively supinate the forearm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain x-ray of the elbow and forearm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen and ice packs reduce pain, inflammation, and edema resulting from fractures and sprains. While the patient's pain with arm motion and on palpation of the arm is consistent with a fracture, the absence of edema, bruising, or other physical deformities makes head subluxation the most likely diagnosis. Appropriate treatment of the radial head subluxation resolves the pain without ibuprofen and ice packs, making this answer an inappropriate next step in management.

B) CORRECT:

Radial head subluxation is the most common elbow injury in children < 5 years of age. It results from sudden traction on the outstretched and pronated arm (e.g., from spinning a child by the hand). The diagnosis is usually made clinically; radiologic imaging is generally not indicated if the patient presents with a typical history and clinical features (i.e., arm held in a flexed and pronated position and tenderness on supination). Treatment consists of closed, manual reduction by forced hyperpronation of the forearm. If hyperpronation is unsuccessful, supination of the forearm with the elbow in flexion can be attempted (under certain circumstances, this supination-flexion technique may be attempted first). Following successful reduction, there is typically immediate pain relief. Reduction can be confirmed if clinical control shows a normal range of motion of the elbow.
Image Description:

Photograph showing hyperpronation technique for reducing a radial head subluxation (also known as pulled elbow or nursemaid's elbow)

Step one (left image): the child's arm is supported at the elbow and wrist, with the examiner's thumb exerting moderate pressure over the radial head.

Step two (right image): the forearm is hyperpronated; a click may be felt as the ligament moves over the radial head

C) INCORRECT:

Splinting the elbow is the appropriate management for radius fractures. While the differential diagnosis for radial head subluxation includes fracture, the absence of edema, bruising, or other evidence of physical deformity make this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Radial head subluxation is the most common elbow injury in children under 5 years old. It results from accidentally pulling the arms of a child too forcefully. This injury alone without bruises or other injuries is not sufficient to warrant concern for child abuse.

E) INCORRECT:

X-ray may be necessary in atypical or treatment-resistant cases of radial head subluxation. However, imaging is usually not required to diagnose radial head subluxation in patients < 5 years of age who present with a typical history and clinical features.
questions.hint: Unwillingness to use an upper limb in a child < 5 years of age with tenderness on supination but no signs of local inflammation is diagnostic of radial head subluxation. The mother likely pulled her daughter's left arm to keep her from falling.

questions.text: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of persistent crying and refusal to move his right arm. The episode began 30 minutes ago after the mother lifted him up by the arms. He appears distressed and is inconsolable. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the patient's right forearm is held close to his body in a flexed and pronated position. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A proximal ulnar fracture (Monteggia fracture) can occur alongside this patient's condition. This fracture is typically caused by either a fall on an outstretched arm or a direct forceful blow to the elbow. Considering the history of this patient, this fracture is unlikely. The clinical presentation would also be more severe.

B) INCORRECT:

An anterior shoulder dislocation causes severe shoulder pain. Unlike in this patient, it usually occurs when falling on an outstretched arm, and the arm is typically held in external rotation and slight abduction. Common complications are axillary nerve and rotator cuff injury.

C) INCORRECT:

Supracondylar humerus fractures are the most common pediatric fractures. These fractures mainly occur in the age group of 5–8 years. This fracture is unlikely to occur from pure traction on an arm. Additionally, we would expect local swelling and potentially a lesion of the median nerve with loss of wrist flexion, thumb opposition, and loss of thenar sensation.

D) INCORRECT:

An olecranon fracture occurs through direct hits to the elbow or falls, which did not happen to this patient. Examination would show local elbow swelling and maybe dislocation of the olecranon.

E) CORRECT:

Radial head subluxation (also referred to as “pulled elbow” or “nursemaid elbow”) describes the slipping of the annular ligament over the radial head that results in partial dislocation of the radial head at the level of the radio-humeral joint. This injury most commonly occurs in children < 5 years of age due to sudden tugging of the outstretched and pronated arm (e.g., pulling of a child's arm to keep them from falling). Clinical features include painful and limited movement of the upper extremity without swelling; the injured individual typically holds their forearm in a flexed and pronated position. The diagnosis is made clinically based on characteristic history and clinical features; radiologic confirmation is usually not required.

Management is conservative and involves closed, manual reduction of the radial head; the radial head can be relocated by hyperpronation of the forearm or supination of the forearm with the elbow in flexion.
questions.hint: This patient presents with the most common elbow injury in children < 5 years of age. It is caused by sudden axial traction on the pronated and extended forearm.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought in for evaluation of her right arm. Her father reports that she has refused to use the arm since earlier today, when he grabbed it to lead her across the street. She has no history of recent falls or other trauma.
During physical examination, she holds her right arm in a slightly flexed and pronated position. There is mild tenderness along the elbow but no bruising or swelling and no point tenderness at the wrist. The girl’s fingers are warm and well perfused, and her radial pulses are normal.
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Imaging should be obtained in a classic presentation of annular ligament displacement only if both reduction methods fail or a single method fails on two attempts. Radiographs are not usually helpful in making the diagnosis, and obtaining them may inadvertently result in reduction of the subluxation when the radiographer supinates the elbow to obtain an anteroposterior view.

B) CORRECT:

Annular ligament displacement — also known as radial head subluxation, dislocated elbow, or nursemaid’s elbow — is one of the most common upper-extremity injuries in children younger than age 6. It typically occurs when a caretaker applies longitudinal traction to a child’s extended arm to avoid a dangerous situation or to help the child onto a step or a curb. It may also occur when a caretaker swings a child around playfully, holding just the child's arms or hands.

Children with annular ligament displacement typically feel pain when moving the injured arm and so will hold that arm still at their side and refuse to bend the elbow or use the arm. During physical examination, the child is typically in no distress, has a flexed elbow, and has a slightly pronated wrist without focal edema, ecchymosis, or gross deformity. Pain and tenderness may be localized to the lateral aspect of the elbow.

When a patient’s history and clinical presentation are classic for annular ligament displacement (as in this case), the most appropriate management is closed reduction. There are two primary methods of reduction, and both are acceptable. In one, the forearm is manually supinated, and the elbow is flexed past 90 degrees. In the other, the forearm is hyperpronated while in the flexed position. With either method, the clinician can expect a palpable or audible click if the reduction is successful. If the initial procedure is not successful, it can be repeated, or the other method can be tried.

Of note, annular ligament displacement is rarely caused by a fall. If a child presents with an elbow injury after falling onto an outstretched hand or falling directly on the elbow, radiographs should be obtained to assess for fracture.

Key learning point: The appropriate management for a young child with suspected annular ligament displacement is closed reduction.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgery is not necessary for annular ligament displacement, even in children who have relatively weak elbow ligaments and are prone to recurrent ligament displacement.

D) INCORRECT:

Imaging should be obtained in a classic presentation of annular ligament displacement only if both reduction methods fail or a single method fails on two attempts.

E) INCORRECT:

Splinting is not necessary either before or after reduction of annular ligament subluxation.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 3-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic by her parents because she refuses to use her left arm after tripping over a stone earlier that morning while holding her mother's hand. She did not fall to the ground. On examination, her left forearm is held close to her body in a flexed and pronated position. There is no swelling or bruising of the elbow or forearm. Palpation of the proximal radius elicits pain, and she cries when you attempt to passively supinate the forearm. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain x-ray of the elbow and forearm.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splinting the elbow is the appropriate management for radius fractures. While the differential diagnosis for radial head subluxation includes fracture, the absence of edema, bruising, or other evidence of physical deformity make this diagnosis unlikely.

Following successful reduction, there is typically immediate pain relief. Reduction can be confirmed if clinical control shows a normal range of motion of the elbow.

Key learning point: Radial head subluxation (nursemaid's elbow) in young children is treated with closed reduction by forced hyperpronation of the forearm, and imaging is unnecessary with classic presentation.

Photograph showing hyperpronation technique for reducing a radial head subluxation (also known as pulled elbow or nursemaid's elbow)

Step one (left image): the child's arm is supported at the elbow and wrist, with the examiner's thumb exerting moderate pressure over the radial head.

Appropriate treatment of the radial head subluxation resolves the pain without ibuprofen and ice packs, making this answer an inappropriate next step in management.

A proximal ulnar fracture (Monteggia fracture) can occur alongside this patient's condition. The clinical presentation would also be more severe.

Supracondylar humerus fractures are the most common pediatric fractures. These fractures mainly occur in the age group of 5–8 years. This fracture is unlikely to occur from pure traction on an arm. Additionally, we would expect local swelling and potentially a lesion of the median nerve with loss of wrist flexion, thumb opposition, and loss of thenar sensation.

An anterior shoulder dislocation causes severe shoulder pain. Unlike in this patient, it usually occurs when falling on an outstretched arm, and the arm is typically held in external rotation and slight abduction. Common complications are axillary nerve and rotator cuff injury.

Management is conservative and involves closed, manual reduction of the radial head; the radial head can be relocated by hyperpronation of the forearm or supination of the forearm with the elbow in flexion.

Key learning point: Radial head subluxation (nursemaid's elbow) typically occurs in young children after sudden pulling of the pronated arm, leading to pain and limited movement with the forearm held flexed and pronated.

An olecranon fracture occurs through direct hits to the elbow or falls, which did not happen to this patient. Examination would show local elbow swelling and maybe dislocation of the olecranon.
questions.hint: This patient presents with the most common elbow injury in children < 5 years of age. It is caused by sudden axial traction on the pronated and extended forearm.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with left arm pain after his mother pulled him up by the hand to prevent him from falling down the stairs. He is holding his arm close to his body with the elbow slightly flexed and pronated. On examination, there is mild point tenderness over the radial head but no swelling, deformity, or ecchymosis. The child cries when his arm is moved. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer procedural sedation before attempting reduction
Perform hyperpronation maneuver with pressure applied to the radial head
Apply a posterior long arm splint with the forearm supinated
Obtain urgent orthopedic consultation for operative management
Obtain anteroposterior and lateral elbow radiographs before intervention

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neither anesthesia nor procedural sedation is required for closed manual reduction of radial head subluxation. The procedure can be performed while the child is awake with appropriate technique and typically causes minimal discomfort.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with classic features of radial head subluxation: a typical mechanism of sudden traction, characteristic arm positioning, mild point tenderness over the radial head, and no swelling or deformity. The hyperpronation maneuver with pressure applied to the radial head is the appropriate first-line reduction technique and can be performed without anesthesia.

C) INCORRECT:

Immobilization is not indicated for the initial management of radial head subluxation. Splinting may be considered for recurrent subluxations or if reduction attempts are unsuccessful, but closed manual reduction should be attempted first.

D) INCORRECT:

Orthopedic consultation is not indicated for typical radial head subluxation with classic features. Orthopedic consultation may be considered if reduction is unsuccessful after repeated attempts, but closed manual reduction in the emergency department should be attempted first.

E) INCORRECT:

Imaging is not routinely performed before reduction in patients with classic clinical features of radial head subluxation. The typical history, mechanism, and examination findings support proceeding directly to treatment without imaging.
